node.title: Utah woman on boating trip dies after fall at Grand Canyon
node.description: Margaret Osswald, 34, is the fourth person to die this year within Grand Canyon National Park, a spokeswoman said.

node.title: Senate set to confirm Jackson to Supreme Court in historic vote
node.description: Jackson is on the cusp of making history as the first Black woman to serve on the nation's highest court.

node.title: Whitmer moves to protect abortion rights in Michigan
node.description: She's proactively suing county prosecutors over 1931 abortion law and asking state Supreme Court to address constitutionality of abortion.

node.title: 2 missing California women found dead in car submerged in river
node.description: Alyssa Ros and Xylona Gama were at a country club for a wedding, but how they ended up in the river is still a mystery.

node.title: Ukrainian soldier who helped push Russia back predicts chemical attacks
node.description: One of the troops that won a battle that "changed the course of the war," and what he fears Russia will do next

node.title: Russian-backed hackers got into Ukrainian military officials' Facebook accounts
node.description: Facebook's parent company, Meta, says they posted videos urging the Ukrainian army to surrender and filed as many as thousands of false reports against users, mainly in Ukraine and Russia, for policy violations.

node.title: Senate to vote on revoking Russia's trade status, oil ban
node.description: The House has already passed both the trade suspension bill and oil ban.

node.title: Abbott says Texas will send charter buses with migrants to D.C.
node.description: The governor said the buses would bring migrants to "the steps of the United States Capitol."

node.title: GOP probe of Hunter Biden's business dealings turns to president's brother James
node.description: GOP Senator Chuck Grassley tells CBS News that his concerns are related to newly obtained banking records.

node.title: Superintendent charged over alleged threatening texts to police chief candidate
node.description: Lynn Clark allegedly sent nearly 100 threatening messages to the police chief candidate, forcing them to withdraw and delaying the election.

node.title: Wind energy company pleads guilty after 150 eagles killed in U.S.
node.description: Almost all of the eagles killed at the NextEra subsidiary's facilities were struck by the blades of wind turbines, prosecutors said.

node.title: Seeking to reach Gen Z, pro-Biden group launches TikTok account
node.description: Building Back Together wants to reach young people with the midterm elections on the horizon.

node.title: ISIS captives were forced to sing "Hotel Osama," hostage testifies
node.description: The ISIS kidnap-and-murder cell known as the "Beatles" held at least 27 foreign hostages in Syria between 2012 and 2015.

node.title: Alex Jones shows up for questioning in Sandy Hook damages lawsuit
node.description: Fines were mounting for his failing to appear. Damages are being determined after a judge ruled he defamed families for claiming the massacre never happened.

node.title: Anger as Turkey decides to let Saudis take over Khashoggi murder trial
node.description: Fiancee of Saudi dissident brutally murdered in kingdom's consulate vows to appeal the move, which a defense lawyer called entrusting "the lamb to the wolf."

node.title: Ukraine: Putin's family, inner circle targeted by US sanctions
node.description: The US has imposed sanctions against Russian President Vladimir Putin's inner circle, including his daughters and relatives of the Foreign Minister.

node.title: NZ Super Fund's wind energy project too big, too expensive - Forsyth Barr
node.description: Investment analysts are casting doubt over the New Zealand Super Fund's major offshore wind energy project.

node.title: Savers keep their cool despite market jitters - ASB survey
node.description: KiwiSaver users are staying put with their investments in the face of financial market volatility caused by the pandemic and geopolitical crises, according to a new survey.

node.title: MidCentral chief executive joins exodus of health bosses
node.description: Another top health boss is resigning - the fifth in the last three days.

node.title: Matariki public holiday passes into law
node.description: The law setting up a Matariki public holiday - set for 24 June this year - has passed in Parliament.

node.title: Students compromise on food to live in damp, mouldy homes
node.description: A survey of tertiary students has found a third of students have mould larger than an A4 sheet of paper growing in their houses at least some of the time.

node.title: Abbott says Texas will sending charter buses with migrants to D.C.
node.description: Abbott said the charter buses would bring migrants to "the steps of the United States Capitol."

node.title: Ed Sheeran wins 'Shape of You' copyright case
node.description: A judge ruled that the singer-songwriter had not plagiarised the 2015 song 'Oh Why' by Sami Chokri. Video

node.title: Eleven-year-old driver among nine youths caught after ram raid at Auckland dairy
node.description: Nine young people - including an 11-year-old driver - have been caught after a dairy in Auckland was ram-raided early this morning.

node.title: Three more ways NZ can add to global pressure on Russia
node.description: Opinion - New Zealand should offer lethal military assistance to Ukraine, reduce the size of the Russian ambassador's office, and help hold war criminals accountable, law professor Alexander Gillespie…

node.title: Commission rejects bid for extra Māori seat on TRC
node.description: A late push for Taranaki Regional Council to have two Māori seats at this year's elections has failed.

node.title: Police launch homicide inquiry after death of woman in her 60s
node.description: The death of a woman who was found at a property in Christchurch is being treated as a homicide.

node.title: Highway between Tokomaru Bay and Te Puia Springs reopens
node.description: The final section of State Highway 35 in Tairāwhiti, north of Gisborne, that was closed by last month's severe weather event reopens to all traffic tomorrow.

node.title: KiwiRail operator reached for phone before locomotive fell into the sea - investigation
node.description: An investigation has found a KiwiRail employee thought he had applied the brakes on a remote-controlled shunt locomotive and went to make a call on his phone, before the engine fell into the sea.

node.title: British PM: Transgender women should not compete in female events
node.description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson says transgender women should not be competing in female sporting events.
